newsitem.title: LITHUANIA: Lithuania to sign trade deals with Slovakia/Czech.
newsitem.headline: Lithuania to sign trade deals with Slovakia/Czech.

text.p: The Baltic state of Lithuania said on Wednesday it hoped to initial free-trade agreements with the Czech and Slovak republics on Thursday or Friday this week.

Czech and Slovak negotiators arrived in Vilnius on Tuesday to hammer out the final details in the pacts, which Lithuania hopes will pave the way for its eventual membership in the Central European Free Trade Association (CEFTA).

"The final talks end on Thursday with the Czech and Slovak sides and we hope to initial free-trade agreements here on Thursday or Friday," a spokesman for the Lithuanian ministry of foreign affairs told Reuters.

Lithuania, which quit the former Soviet Union in 1991, is keen on joining CEFTA, an economic grouping of former Communist bloc states comprising Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary and Slovenia.
Czech-Lithuanian trade was worth just over $65 million in 1995, up from almost $54 million in 1994.
Lithuania signed a free trade agreement with neighbour Poland in June and needs similiar agreements with all CEFTA members before it can join the association.
Aside from Lithuania, Latvia, Romania, Bulgaria and Ukraine aee also knocking at CEFTA's door.
